review_title: If I could give no stars I would
pros: That it was a paying job
cons:
This is long overdue, but the experience I had working here was so bad, that I couldn't write an objective critique.

CIPD is a terrible company to work for. Considering that this company creates the qualifying standard for all HR professionals they really don't practice what they preach.

I took the job there because my partner works in HR and she said that they would be a decent employer. How wrong she was. After having sacked a number of people who made up my department me and my manager were hired. Even though my hours were 9 to 5 I was regularly expected to work extra hours with no compensation. My manager however was given days in lieu for his overtime. When I had a baby, even though I had booked time off I was expected to come in the next day, because technically I wasn't entitled to Paternity Leave. This was mainly due to the fact that my manager was on holiday skiing, even though I let him know that the birth was imminent. 

There was also a culture of selective "diversity". If you are black, don't expect to get promoted (there were no black managers, even though there were a number of black people who had worked there for 10 years or more),and don't expect more than a 1% pay rise, don't expect to be given a permanent job before the 2 year mark if you are hired as a temp. Also if you are black and your position is made redundant, don't expect them to give you a redundancy payment. You will more than likely be given the choice of working in Customer Services and if this isn't to your liking you will have to leave with a month's notice as they offered you an alternative role which you turned down. If you are black and you are bullied by your managers and complain to HR don't expect any support, as there will be none. What you should expect is for your managers and HR to collude on a strategy on how to manage you out.

The majority of this companies' revenue isn't made from selling HR courses, it is actually made from advising companies on how to keep their staff in line and advising them on how much they can get away with. Considering that this company sets the HR standards in the UK, it's no wonder there are so many terrible work places out there.

This company was so bad that for the sake of my mental health I had to leave, giving no notice. I've never done that before, but I couldn't take working there any more. On Sunday evenings I couldn't eat and I couldn't sleep knowing I had to go into this nightmare on Monday.

To anyone out there looking at this company for future employment, I'd say approach with caution. To any black people out there I'd say avoid like the plague.

review_title: Can't believe this is an HR company
pros: Some amazing people to work with who are genuinely passionate about what they do
cons:
Honestly dismayed that they can be telling other organisations how to handle bullying and wellbeing when the organisation itself doesn't follow their own advice. People going off sick with stress and no sign of support from senior leadership - actually I think they're completely oblivious to the welfare of the people that work for them.
I joined the CIPD because I believed in supporting the better work and working lives of people across the globe, but have been terribly unhappy and stressed out. There is a culture of work until you drop and if you complain then you're the odd one.
No progression or reward for your hard work either.

review_title: Lovely people, best place I worked at
pros:
- Great bunch of people to work with. Many have worked there for years and I could see why.
- Work/life balance was good and the dept I was in were flexible with appointments, events etc.
- Open plan office that allowed for interaction with many different people
- Good benefits also + fun events during Christmas, Summer etc.
- Work was still manageable even during stressful times
cons:
- Not all decisions from the top trickled down well to the bottom
- Pay could've been much better but the work itself compensated for this.

review_title: Hierarchical workplace that is toxic behind the facade
pros: Flex working, a couple of nice colleagues
cons:
The CIPD is incredibly hierarchical internally. Favouritism takes place a lot and opportunities to progress are given to some and not others. The CIPD does not practice what it preaches and can be a very toxic environment.
Long standing senior staff members are the cause of this.

review_title: HR Institute full of narcissistic people that trails all the way to their international offices
pros: Some really nice people especially the admins and non managers
cons: Conceited, arrogant “heads of” departments rife with narcissistic people who think........they’re the experts in people and HR

review_title: Nice place to work but culture of nepotism, stagnation and superficiality let it down.
pros:
* Some absolutely lovely staff/colleagues.
* Flexible working.
* Free lunch.
* Opportunities to get involved in additional projects.
cons:
* Limited progression opportunities for hard working staff.
* Tendency to reward those with the 'gift of the gab' rather than those who deliver tangible output for the business.
* Rife with nepotism. 
* Passive-aggressive culture.
* Business is astonishingly slow at implementing meaningful change.
* Senior management often seem more preoccupied with the company public image rather than addressing its' internal operations/infrastructure/staff concerns.
* Lack of inclusion and diversity in some directorates (e.g. particular directorates more than 90% white heterosexual female only). Odd for a company publicly proclaiming itself as "diverse and inclusive".

pros: Nice office location, bright, free lunch from cafeteria and a friendly atmosphere
cons:
There is strong capability at the management level however, as you move up to ET or the Executive Team there is a real lack of managerial skills and the kind of backgrounds and performance one would expect at that level.  Most of the departments managers are more capable than their directors.

There is a very passive aggressive culture here were you have to agree with what the ET leader or CEO says.  Providing any kind of questions or concerns is met with seemingly kind but very clear obstacles so you learn quickly to smile and say YES!  

What is surprising is that in the whole company of around 300 people only around 5 have any idea about HR or have ever worked in real HR jobs.  This is shocking and very dangerous for a Chartered Institute for HR!   A lot of what we do is very dated, not actually researched as speaking to 5 companies does not constitute research in my view, and needs to be more progressive.

pros: office is close to the station
cons: line managers not very friendly

pros: Flexibility, benefits, Friendly environment, customer oriented
cons: Technical progression, pay, career growth

review_title: Talk is Cheap. Big ideas - Small on action.
pros:
1. Free lunch.
2. Getting involved in work groups like LGBT, BAME, WELLBEING, SPORTS, WINE CLUB.
3. Xmas £150 vouchers to spend anywhere.
4. Social get togethers.
cons:
1. Nepotism & Cronyism is rife!! Career development is talked up a lot, but rarely happens, takes a long time, and usually given to a friend, or even family member.  2. Diversity, inclusion and culture is poor - Suggestions are made, apparently listened to BUT NOTHING EVER HAPPENS OR CHANGES - and not 1 person on the senior leadership/management team is from an ethic minority - as someone in a mixed race relationship, this is very sad to see. 3. So many talented people have been, rightly, employed and brought into the organisation, however, due to being frustrated at either the lack of opportunities or empty promises - we have lost some truly outstanding talent.  I hope we can change, and quickly.
4. Salaries - are lower than the industry averages.

review_title: No room for career development and management are clueless in regards to employee dissatisfaction
job_title: Marketing Account Manager in London, England
pros: Free lunch, beautiful office and 20 minutes away from central London and they have discovery hour which gives you the chance to find out what's happening in the business.
cons: There isn't any opportunity for career growth. You will meet a lot of people and by that I mean 80% of them who will be on executive level who are extremely experienced and really excellent at what they do but because of the structure of the company are stuck at executive level with no chance of promotion to manager level. No one actually takes the time to introduce themselves or to get to know you and managers certainly don't know what they are doing with every question you ask being deferred to someone else.

pros: nice office environment, friendly staff, flexible working, free lunch, generous holiday allowance: overall great employee perks
cons: you think you're going into a great career opportunity only to realise you spend 99% of your time following unproductive, outdated, tedious processes (with awful systems which have been poorly implemented) and having pointless meetings with many stakeholders who are all unnecessarily involved in your projects/decision making. micro manage culture and lack of creative freedom made the job frustrating and demotivating, which is a huge shame as the company itself is a good employer

review_title: If you’re coming to CIPD because you’re fooled by the image they project, head for the hills.
pros:
•	The low-performance culture means that the work is easy
•	Work life balance is very good
•	Free lunch
•	You can be yourself at work 
•	Office is nice, and a nice location
cons:
•	Very weak leadership – slow (almost non-existent) decision making
•	Lack of strategy – lots of vague aims but no metrics/articulation/idea of how to get there
•	Big disconnection from the purpose. CIPD is more concerned with furthering its own image than actually doing anything tangible to help either its members or the general public
•	Lack of opportunities for development and progression
•	EXTREME cronyism
•	Salary for some is very high (for no apparent reason – it’s not linked to performance) and for many others is very low

pros: flexible working, no real performance measures
cons:
Constant change and restructures
Constant change in reporting lines and SLT
Clicques and favourites are clear
No international strategy 
Poor service at home for our majority of members
Charity with no charitable purpose in my view

review_title: Intentions are great, let down by poor management

cons: Some leaders do not embody what CIPD does in the world of HR and L&D.  Lack of communication and engagement with staff, they are trying but not always investing in the best channels.

review_title: Great people, great development and now, great direction

cons: Little opportunity for promotion at mid-managament level.  Not everyone feels able to speak out or is heard when new strategy/ideas are being considered.

review_title: Check career progress before you sign up!

cons: Very difficult to move  job bands. Tendency to bring in new recruits over existing staff so opportunities for development are limited.  Would also agree other comments about the Exec Team, mostly full of their own self-importance to speak to staff though there are a few exceptions.
